I've found that I never need to construct test suites. My package 
structure combined with my test cases naturally dictate my suite 
structure. In order to run my tests I simply use a utility that I 
wrote to discover the tests in the packages. 

Has anyone else found the construction of test suites to be largely a 
waste of time? IMO, if you use packages properly, then you should 
never need to construct a test suite. 

For instance, to find and run all the tests on my current project I 
just need to type the following at the command line.

java MyTestFinder com

"com" is the root package for the system. My utility then recursively 
goes through the packages and runs all the test cases it can find. 

So I can selectively test a particular package

java MyTestFinder com.dotcomfailure.mycode

Or... if you need to run a single test...

java MyTestFinder com.dotcomfailure.mycode.SimpleTestCase

Running tests this way, I never have to worry about adding a main 
method to any of my test cases to run them. Also, I don't have to 
worry about maintaining TestSuites. The greatest benefit that I see 
is that when I run all the tests, I know without a doubt that every 
single test case in the entire system was run. I don't have to worry 
about a test case not getting run b/c someone forgot to add it to a 
test suite. 

I know Ant has the ability to find all tests, so anyone can take this 
aproach. However, Ant finds test based on pattern matching, which can 
lead to problems b/c then a naming standard has to be enforced.

I'm new to this group, so let me know if this has already been 
discussed.

Regards,

Mike
